question: Question_01_(d)
sols:
Let's first check if the summands of the offered series go to zero.

\begin{align*}
\lim_{kÂ \rightarrow \infty} k^{-2} &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac1{k^2} = 0. \\
\lim_{kÂ \rightarrow \infty} \frac1{k} &= 0. \\
\lim_{kÂ \rightarrow \infty} k &= \infty. \\
\lim_{kÂ \rightarrow \infty} (1.01)^k &= \infty. \\
\lim_{kÂ \rightarrow \infty} k^2 &= \infty.\end{align*}

Thus iii., iv., and v. can not converge. But the series i. and ii. are
candidates for convergent series.

By a pairwise comparison of the summands of series i. and series ii. we
see that \emph{k\textsuperscript{-2} \textless{} 1/k}, and hence (Series
i.) \textless{} (Series ii.). We are told that only one series
converges, so it can only be Series i. (If Series ii. would converge,
and (Series i.) \textless{} (Series ii.), then Series i. would also
converge.)

Indeed this is true, by the p-series test with \emph{p = 2}.

\textbf{Thus, the correct answer is i.}

Fun fact: $\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}k^{-2} = \frac{\pi^{2}}{6}.$
